document.masterDocTitle: Urban Scatopsidae (Diptera) of Los Angeles, California, United States

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Urban Scatopsidae (Diptera) of Los Angeles, California, United States

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Depto. de Biologia, FFCLRP, Universidade de São Paulo, Av. Bandeirantes, 3900,14040 - 901, Ribeirão Preto, SP, Brazil,

subSubSection.paragraph:
Coboldia fuscipes ( Meigen, 1830 )
: 314 (
Scatopse
). Type locality: ‘Europe’.
Diagnosis. Orange-brown. Male tergite 8 with a medial elongate, asymmetrical spatulate projection, aedeagus very long, coiled; female sternite 7 with a medial bare emargination on posterior margin.

Remarks.
Coboldia fuscipes
is the most widespread scatopsid species known. Its larvae have been found in very different kinds of environments: there are records of larvae connected to a variety of decaying organic matter of vegetal and animal origin ( Haenni and Vaillant, 1994 ). The larvae, pupae, and biology were described in detail by Rabello and Forattini (1962) . Cook (1975) refers to adults of this species reared from
Echinocactus polycephalus
.

Coboldia fuscipes
showed up in the samples of 21 out of the 47 BioSCAN collecting sites. There is an obvious peak of emergence in mid-spring, in April and May, with some additional catches in late autumn. The Bold Systems database has 52 sequenced specimens of
C. fuscipes
, from North America and Europe, all belonging to a single cluster (http://boldsystems.org/index.php/ Public_SearchTerms?query=%22 Coboldia %20fuscipes%22[tax]).
